snippet: In a mysterious standoff, millipedes abide by a 140-mile boundary they rarely cross, a study found.
abstract: Study published by Bob Melsboy in journal Zoo Keys reports two species of millipedes maintaining a 140-mile boundary, which neither will cross, on the Australian island of Tasmania; boundary is especially mysterious because borders between species usually follow a natural geographic divide.
lead_paragraph: In a mysterious standoff, millipedes abide by a 140-mile boundary they rarely cross, a study found.

headline.print_headline: A Tasmanian Maginot Line For Two Millipede Species
headline.seo: A Standoff Between Two Species of Millipedes on Tasmania
headline.main: A Tasmanian Maginot Line for Two Millipede Species
